title: Zoo of logging frameworks
body:
During the work on [553877](https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=553877) spend some time investigating logging frameworks used in *Eclipse Passage*. Results are interesting and worth to be discussed. 

### We use 
 - **JUL**  directly,
 - **OSGi logging** in *some* equinox-based bundles,
 - **SLF4J** in a sporadic way,
 - **Jetty logging** for `JettyServer`

### How we do this
1. **JUL** directly
    - all the `*Messages.java`
    - org.eclipse.passage.`lbc.internal.equinox`.conditions.ServerConditionArbiter
   -  org.eclipse.passage.`lic.internal.equinox`.requirements.BundleCapabilityResolver
    - org.eclipse.passage.`lic.internal.hc`.HcConditionMiner
    - org.eclipse.passage.`loc.internal.licenses`.core.LicenseMailSupport
    - org.eclipse.passage.`loc.workbench`.dialogs
2. **OSGi logging**
    - org.eclipse.passage.`lbc.internal.equinox`.ServerRunnerImpl
    - org.eclipse.passage`.lic.internal.equinox`.requirements.ComponentConfigurationResolver
3. **SLF4J**
     - org.eclipse.passage`.lbc.internal.equinox`.conditions.AcquireConditionActionExecutor
     - org.eclipse.passage.`lic.hc`.HttpRequests
     - org.eclipse.passage.`loc.internal.workbench`.LocDomainRegistryAccess
 
### Findings
1. One physical package exploits several logging frameworks 
2. Each particular framework does not seem to have a peculiar reason to be used here or there. 
 
### Question
Should we put things here in some order? 

### Suggestion
I think, that, for understandable causes (like, say, logging configuration),
 there should be
 -  either a static choice (like, JUL) 
 - or some reasonable strategy for choosing a framework. 
    Like:
      - OSGi logging for OSGi/Equinox dependent packages  
      - [SLF4J+JUL](http://jkssweetlife.com/configure-slf4j-working-various-logging-frameworks) for the rest of the bundles

What do you think, colleagues?

title: Customer notification feature
body:
Here is new feature under construction.  This meta-issue is dedicated to discussions and approriate BugZilla tickets tracking. 

### Statement
Licansing Operator Client knows a lot about customers - who are they, which products they are interested in, when and which licenses have been issues for them, - all the stuff. 

The idea of the feature is to use this information to _notify_ a customer of relevant events - new releases, actions, whatever. 

### Workflow suggested
How an operator gonna do this? 

In a sentence, one is going to export the *customer base* to **csv** file(s) with all necessary information, and then, occasionaly, send hand-crafted mails to subset of this base - with or without  help of Passage. 

### Tasks
1. CSV export 
   - invent a csv format with the all information enough for the basic use case
   - implement export of *customer base* to this format.
  
2. Notification
   - provide a way for an operator to easily select a subset from *customer base*, basing on some criteria (like, say, product line of interest)
   - provide a way for an operator to send pregenerated/hand-crafted  notification mails to the customers for a subset

    According to the current vision, all actual mail sending is currently happens without Passage been involved.

title: IDE: PDE Integration should help complete licensing scenario
body:
Now a developer, who is responsible for integrating Passage into it's product-under=development (in order to make it a product-under-licensing), has access to Passage template project `Passage for e4 RCP`. 

This sample project does a lot of useful work and finally reveals Passage governance: been run, such an RCP product exposes a licensing dialog conveying "no license" status and related practical details. 

In te scope of this task we should also make it easy for this developer to complete the licensing scenario. 

How exactly? We have a plan.

1. Near the sample `e4 rcp` project, right in the same workspace, generate two more projects. These guys are to contain all the pregenerated work result we assume to be done in our Operator Client in order to `issue a license` and thus complete the licensing scenario.

2. The first additional project, `e4 rcp maser`, should contain meta-data of our sample-product-under-licensing marketing infrastructure: `product line`, `features`, `feature versions`, etc. 
Recommended structure:
 - e4.rcp.master
   - licensing
     - features/  (xmi-files here)
     - products/  (xmi-files here)
     - ... (folders for other required passage configuration model structures)

All these `features` and `products` folders contain sufficient set of emf model files that are available for editing with EMF tooling (which must be installed preliminarily, and this step needs to be described somewhere in the `master` project as well).

3. The second additional projects `e4 rcp operator` is to contain pregenerated set of business-sensitive part of passage data such as product keys, customer base and issues licenses. 
Recommended structure:
- e4.rcp.master
   - licensing
     - keys/      (xmi-files here)
     - users/     (xmi-files here)
     - licenses/  (xmi-files here)
     ...

4. Describe both projects exhaustively (say, in one's README files). Explain type and dedication of artifacts generated, they roles in licensing scenario, requirements/best practices for the artifacts keeping. Like, `e4 rcp operator` should not share vcs repository with `e4 rcp master` as the former one aggregates business-sensitive data and should be accessible by persons with higher privileges.

5. Put (say, in a base project's README) an instruction for further steps with all necessary details: how (and where from) to download Operator Client, how to open additionally generated files there, how to actually issue a license. 


The task is general and is intended to be decomposed.

title: Operator: Workspace
body:
All the Operator functioning is spinning around creating and managing artifacts of the following types
  - metadata for products and customerst
  - product version keys
  - issued licenses

Currently we store them in home-dir with not much of a structure, which makes the long-term management and migrations complicated. 

The idea is to exploit Eclipse Workspace for the purpose. 

```
------------------------------------------------------------
Draft of the workspace structure is the following  
 - /features (*.features_xmi files to keep Feature Sets)
 - /products (*.products_xmi to keep Product Lines)
 - /users    (*.users_xmi to manage Customers and Users)
 - /plans    (*.licenses_xmi to keep License Plans)
 - /keys     (storage for generated keys for Product Versions)
 -   /<product-id>
 -      /<product-version>
 -         <product-id>_<product-version>.pub
 -         <product-id>_<product-version>.scr
 - /issued   (all issued licenses)
 -   /<product-id>
 -      /<product-version>
 -         /<user-origin>
 -            /floating (floating liecnse packs)
 -               /*<floating-license-pack-id>
 -            /personal
 -               /<user-id>  (personal licenses)
 -                  *.lic
 -                  *.licen
               
------------------------------------------------------------
```

For a company, which uses Operator to issu licenses only for it's own product lines there can be only one Workspace of this structure. 

For a service centers, that supplies license issuing and management for another vendors' products, there should be one Workspace per vendor.

As it's been found during discussions, all the data relative to a product licensing can be separated to three groups, each of which 
 - has a particular lifecycle
 - is managed by a used of distinct role, 
 - defines it's own rules of visibility and access, 
 - has particular level of sencibility and business value 
 - assumes distinguishable scenarios for data loss prevension

[1] 'definition': products and features are usually declared by development/ management, amended rarely and forms a ground for  
[2] 'evolution' data: product versions and feature versions (deliveries) managed by development, amended incrementally
[3] 'licening' artifacts: 
 - customer dase, 
 - encryption keys, 
 - license plans definition, 
 - actually issued license packs. 
In general case licensing activity 
 - is performed outside of development and dev management, 
 - deals with sencitive data (like maybe user personal information) and
 - business-valuable data (like customer base, product version keys, issued licenses). 
This part of a licensing project should be 
 - kept separately, 
 - available for a tight circle of operation officers
 - be maintained with regular secure backups

This separation should establish a base for the future product licensing workspace.

It is presisted as a String emf-property, without a format demands. The property's editor also does not restrict format.

1. User's favorite expression must be exposed for editing as a list of key-value pairs, where keys are not arbitrary, but supplied by all supported `Environment` implementations.

title: Licensing Agent
body:
Licensing Agent is an http-server, that 
 - takes a `ic.api.Passage`-like request (simpl put: can I use a feature or not)  
 - runs the request against it's own _Access Cycle_
 - responds via http according to the results

The idea is to license any application, even those who are not based on Eclipse or even Java.

An application under licensing communicates with the Agent via http, persists requests and parses responses with it's own facilities. Though, we are to offer basic dev components for key platforms (like node.js).

First LA impementaion should:
 - serve 'canUse' request
 - rely on the existing xml content type for payloads

Further:
 - serve 'acquire' and 'release' requests
 - support json payloads content type

title: FLS needs user interaction on startup - cannot be used as system daemon
body:
Hi there, 

currently the floating license server requires user interaction to fully start up, i.e. press  "p" to start the server.
This makes it impossible to use the fls as system daemon that automatically starts with your server computer.

It is unlikely and undesirable in any deployment scenario to require a human to interact with the server startup.
Why require user interaction here when it is not needed?

Compare to a webserver, a file server, any other server. Some of them have debug or interactive modes, but those are not the default.
Therefore, I suggest changing the startup behavior to always assume  "p", and add a new command line parameter, e.g. -interactive
that then shows the menu at startup.

Best regards
Jens

@jensgw  thank you for your interest. 

FLS has not been designed as a deamonable server mostly because it intended to have wide interaction with admin, for exmple
 - to deploy a product license under the server
 - to perform diagnnostic monitoring during the server operation, etc

Meaning FLS needs interaction not only on startup.

So it's not the matter of one more cli-option invention. If we desire to have a deamon (background) mode, we demand operating without terminal (without interaction).  

Having this described, I would rather state the feature proposal as _Redesign FLS to support deamon launch_ .

body:
Yes, agreed on the "Redesign FLS to support deamon launch".

Currently we do some testing with passage and FLS and see if it fits in our infrastructure. Immediately apparent was that the server component does not behave as a typical server would.

We would very much like a daemon mode, no console no terminal, if there are issues there is a log file the server can write to.

Requiring user interaction binds human resources, no server does that. That begs the question, why does passage behave differently? Assuming correct setup: a server should start up and begin operations and should never require any form of user interaction, problems are logged in a log file. There can be a debug mode where the server runs in foreground and logs are also displayed on the console. Compare to apache2, freeradius, etc. basically everything that calls itself server.

In general, if user interaction is needed it should be split out in a separate component, e.g. floating license server and floating license server control client. The later can be a client that connects to the server and can send commands.

Have the fls running on a remote machine, for some reason that needs to reboot, and now all users have to wait for an admin to press p before they can get licenses. Depending on how many admins a company has, that might take a minute, or days ...
Additionally a server that needs user input does not scale. Imagine a  large deployment of fls to lets say 38473 servers in a cloud environment. Those servers do not operate unless every one of them got the keypress p.

title: FLS cannot define server bind address
body:
Hi there,

currently the server port of the floating license server can be specified with -server.port, this is good.

However, there is no option to specify the binding address, instead the "wildcard" 0.0.0.0 is always used, which translates to "use all addresses of this system". This assumes either
- that a server has only one network interface and that this network interface has only one address
or
- that the server should always listen on all addresses of the system.
Both assumptions are wrong.

A network interface can have multiple addresses. A server can, and usually has, multiple network interfaces. 
In most cases the server software (fls) should only listen on one address.

Therefore, I suggest to add a command line parameter to specify the binding address of the server, e.g. -server.bindaddress.
I have prepared a working solution to either provide a binding address, or assume as default to listen on all addresses.
Technically -server.bindadress should be a list of addresses. However, the solution mentioned above covers most use cases and is a starting point.

Best regards
Jens

title: Support stable prioritization of MinedConditions
body:
In situations where multiple mined-conditions are available to satisfy a requirement it would be very convenient if there were means to prioritize certain conditions over others. From my observation it is currently random which condition is selected (i.e. depends on the order of elements in a HashMap/-Set).

For example we are using a custom access-cycle configuration that uses two `LocalConditions` and one `RemoteConditions` miner, similar like the `FocusedAccessCycleConfiguration.Wide` configuration does, so this issue probably also applies to all that use that config.
When a user has a operational floating server available plus a valid local personal license, it would be good if the Access-Cyle would always select the personal and acquires the corresponding grant over the floating-license.
This reduces the number of occupied floating seats without the need to disable the floating license locally.

At the moment I can think of two ways to implement this:
- Ensure the miner registries establish a stable order (e.g. via LinkedHashMap to maintain the order of the passed List) to get a stable condition order in the following process.
The priorities are then implicitly defined in the AccessCycleConfiguration through the order of the condition miners passed to the registry.
- Assign priorities to MinedConditions according to which the mined valid conditions are sorted before one is finally selected to satisfy a requirement
The priorities are then defined explicitly by assigning an integer priority to each condition.

The first approach seems to be a bit simpler to implement to me but has the disadvantage that it the priorities are not explicitly modeled and that it has to be ensured that the order is also maintained in the entire mining process.

If you are interested I can offer to provide a PR to implement this in the way you prefer.

Been that said, the feature looks worthful. 

Adding `priority` property to `MinedConditions` interface is not an option now. It is mature interface and it's worth lots of thinking to add anything to it.

title: Support requirement for multiple values in Hardware evaluation expression
body:
For hardware elements that can have multiple instances on a usual computer, like Network-Adapters or drives, one sometimes wants to ensure that that multiple instances with certain properties are present and/or that only a fixed set of instances (and not more) with certain properties is present.
In those cases it would be useful to enhance hardware expression evaluation to support the following:

- Parse multiple values for the same expression key and evaluate each value. This is PR #1115.
With that it would be possible to define an expression like `hwdisk.serial=123;hwdisk.serial=456`, which then requires the computer to have at least one disk with serial `123` and one disk with serial `456`.
- Add means to specify that there must not be more respectively that there are only exactly those elements (network-adapters, drives) than those that are specified in the expression.
So if one defines an expression `hwdisk.serial=123;hwdisk.serial=456` (and something to enable the 'no-more'-mode) then the execution computer must have exactly one drive with serial `123` and one drive with serial `456` and no more.

Either the Berlin protocol could be enhanced or this could be implemented in an own protocol. In general I think this could be interesting for others as well and therefore wanted to propose that as change within Passage instead of just implementing a custom protocol.

title: NA
body:
Dear @HannesWell, thank you very much for you interest in these deep levels of condition assessment. 

Must say, Berlin protocol is simple by design and must stay this way. It found wide use in production and proved to be sufficient as it is. 

Passage API offers full set of condition assessment interfaces and the way to contribute them to the runtime of Passage core. These are your means, that we desigend for cases like this, intended to be used for the purposes of extension. 

I must emphsize, this is very much important point: Passage architecture offers huge lots of extensions exactly for the cases as yours. We discourage modifications in the favour of extensions, as having API this rich is a burden on our resources, taken deliberately, as we built Passage on best design practices, including _open for extension / closed for modification_ principle.  

In case you think your new idea of assessment could be interesting for others, I would recommend you to use supplied interfaces to implement your own library. It can reside, for example, on maven. Thus it could be used by any interested party for any product, protected by Passage. 

Feel free to post an issue here in case you find something impossible to implement or plug with the current state of API .

The Feature `org.eclipse.passage.lbc.target.feature` contains some dependencies of passage bundles with a fixed versions (due to how Tycho/P2 builds them) that are from a previous Eclipse releases.
The Feature `org.eclipse.passage.lbc.execute.feature` requires `o.e.passage.lbc.target.feature` and therefore forces the content of the latter to be present in the TP or application. Because the target-feature contains Plug-ins that are singletons the `passage.lbc.execute.feature` for Passage 2.5 cannot be used with with the recent Eclipse 2022-09 features in one Target-Platform.

Because PDE and P2/Tycho (can) add required dependencies of Plugins to a launched or build Eclipse product automatically there is actually no need to have a target feature.
Therefore I suggest to remove the dependency to `o.e.passage.lbc.target.feature` from `o.e.passage.lbc.execute.feature`.
I can provide a PR to do that.

title: Don't require log4j-core for o.e.passage.lic.base
body:
At the moment the Plug-in `org.eclipse.passage.lic.base` imports the package `org.apache.logging.log4j.core.config` because it uses classes from it in the class `org.eclipse.passage.lic.internal.base.logging.Logging`.
This causes problem for those that don't want to use log4j-2 as logging framework implementation in their application. In such cases one uses a bridge bundle that redirect all calls to the log4j-2 API to the actually used Logging-framwork implementation, for example logback. There are corresponding bundles for that and that works fine.
But the package `org.apache.logging.log4j.core.config` is not part of the log4j.api bundle but only of the log4j.core bundle (both are from Maven-Central, not from Eclipse-Orbit, which is a modified form). Therefore `o.e.passage.lic.base` requires log4j.core even if that is not used in the corresponding application and `o.e.passage.lic.base` is required by many other Passage plugins, which then transitivly pull in log4j too.

Therefore I want to ask you to make `log4j-core` not a required for `o.e.passage.lic.base` anymore.
Currently I can think about two ways how this could be achieved:
- Make Package-Import `org.apache.logging.log4j.core.config` optional in the Manifest.
Then  `o.e.passage.lic.base` is only wired to log4j-core, if another Plug-in or Feature with a non-optional requirement adds it to the application but it does not pull in log4j-core into apps launched from the IDE or build by Tycho/P2.
- Move the `Logging` class to a less basic Plug-in and remove the package-import entirely from passage.lic.base
Maybe `o.e.passage.lic.execute`, which also uses it and can export it to `o.e.passage.loc.operator.seal`.
But for the use in `org.eclipse.passage.lic.jetty` the class either has to be copied or the latter plug-in also has to depend on passage.lic.execute, but I don't know if that is wanted.

I can provide a PR implementing the approach you prefer.

title: Extend license assessment with context
body:
It appeared to be important for assessing unit to beware of context it is called in. 

A client have a very much casual case:
  - product is quite functional itself
  - is also supplies set of functions under their own licensing protection - each function is covered  by its own licensing feature. 
  - for reasons that we should not try to fathom the client builds binary distribution from the whole codebase: product core and all the supplementary functions together. 

Now client issues a license with the only grant - for the core of the product, whithout any additional functions.

On the first startup license assessment is performed and the license is imported. Assessing unit finds that lots of features are not covered by this license and reasonably decides to issue negative certificate.  Which leads user to a frustration: they experience incapacity to fix things. 
On the next launch everything goes smoothly, but not every client makes to the second run before posting support ticket. 

If only assessing unit knew circumstances of the appeal
  - whether it called in general context to widely inform user of its license coverage state, 
  - or in precise feature access request

that whould let the unit behave more user friendly.

Now this general license time slot is ignored, but should be used. 
Or killed.

body:
> * what exactly causes these failures

The change from https://github.com/eclipse-passage/passage/pull/1356 e.g. in `ProductOperatorServiceImpl` requires SCR 1.3 because the `Field Strategy` or `Field Injection`, i.e. using `@Reference` at fields, described in chapter `112.3.3` is only available since 1.3 of the OSGi DS spec (which has a different version than the overall OSGi release):

- https://docs.osgi.org/download/r6/osgi.cmpn-6.0.0.pdf
- https://docs.osgi.org/specification/osgi.cmpn/8.1.0/service.component.html#service.component-field.injection

In version DS version 1.2 chapter `112.3 References to Services` does not support that:
https://docs.osgi.org/download/r5/osgi.cmpn-5.0.0.pdf

> * why only these two components failed to load

I assume `@Reference` is not on fields used anywhere else.


Btw. if you contemplate to revert the change mentioned above, my suggestion would be to just continue with #1362 to fix the SCR files since 1.3 is supported by the Felix SCR (which is used by Eclipse) since 2015:
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FELIX-4406
So requiring SRC 1.3 isn't a strong requirement.

On the long run I would furthermore continue with https://github.com/eclipse-passage/passage/issues/1365 to avoid such synchronization errors in total in the future.

title: [LOC] OSGi EventListener not usable like LicensePackIssueListener

Using an OSGi EventListener registered (e.g. as DS component) for the topics
- `org/eclipse/passage/loc/api/OperatorLicenseEvents/decodedIssued`
- `org/eclipse/passage/loc/api/OperatorLicenseEvents/encodedIssued`

- Events are processed asynchronously (`EventAdmin.postEvent()` vs `EventAdmin.sendEvent()`)
- Evens are only fired for personal licenses, not floating licenses

If both points are implemented, using an OSGi `EventListener` can even be more powerful since the `decodedIssued` event is fired before the the encoding happens, which allows to enhance the issued decoded license file before it is encoded. This can for example be used to issue Passage 2 complaint files with Passage 3.

Originally we designated _raw string identifiers_ to convey user-product licensing decisions to _Passage Runtime Engine_.

Production practice of Passage integrations maintenance reveals that _raw string identifier_ approach lacks semantic severely and thus affects one of the most critical integration feat.

Support reports direct correlation between absence of differentiating for _raw string identifiers_  - on one hand, and elongated implementation time with higher expences - on the other.

Hereby it is agreed to take steps to improve codebase in this aspect by eliminating raw strings that serve as identifiers for licensing configuration information and replacing them with entities that are to carry not only string information, but also shoulder semantic weight.

Key focus should rest with integration API: `Passage` interface, _Access Cycle configuration_ interfaces and all the surronding facilities that developer of a product uses to protect the product with Passage. 

The rest of API  also should be revised from this perspective, as integration experience proves again and again that practically each extension point of the _Passage Runtime Engine_ gets used every so often.

title: Add contract test for `FeatureIdentifier`
body:
Extracted from https://github.com/eclipse-passage/passage/pull/1454#pullrequestreview-2425833697 by @eparovyshnaya 

`FeatureIdentifier` interface is used by core, among other ways, as a key to HashMaps. 
This usage lies obligations on this interface (`hashCode()` and `equals()` impls should be in synch).

The only implementation of this interface is `record`, so it meets the requirement automatically. But custom implementations of  Access Cycle Configuration services can potentially supply their own implementation for `FeatureIdentifier` interface as well. 

This  means that there should be a contract test for this interface. 

We rely on `FeatureIdentifier` implementation to
 - do not tolerate `null` as construction input
 - have synchronous `equals()` and `hashCode()`, meaning different instances, constructed with equal strings, beget `true` for `equals()` and have the same `hashCode()`.

This contract test must be implemented for `BaseFeatureIdentifier`.

title: From-The-Box Support for optional license storage
body:
Passage API has an extension point to supply license data for the Engine.  

All existing implementations, delivered with the existing Passage packages, that survey local file system, are strict by design - they do not tolerate a location, if it does not exist on the local file system. 

Meanwhile, there is a demand for lenient approach too. A product can configure a license residence, that can be completely ommitted in some editions of the product (like evaluation license for limited edition, academic license for educational edition, so on). 

Not a biggie, as in this case product development just implements their own extension from scratch as there is nothing for this case in-the-box.  That's what the extension point for.

But these cases multiply, and it grows more and more _nice_ of Passage to support optional behaviour right in-the-box.

title: Lllet my people goooo! (ubiquitous `quit` option for CLI license checker)
body:
Under the terms of the provisional API Passage ships basic CLI utilities to facilitate license-related interations with user for CLI-applications. 

In this scope there is a simplistic `LicenseCoverageCheck` to serve as regular License Dialog, but in CLI: it 
 - makes an initial assessment, 
 - offers user ways to proceed, 
 - takes user's decision, does what user asked, 
 - offers following options
 - and so keeps going on and on, until ~death do them part~ user decides either quit or finally is granted with the ability to launch the app and does so. 

This basic functions appear to be sufficient to many cases, so it's widely used. 

One of the usage, encountered recently, exploited this interactive facility in blind, automated mode. And it appeared that this interactive util is not suited for such an apprach as it does not offer `quit` option in case of successful assessment. Meaning user, who does not have problems with license coverage, can only proceed with the application launch (and then exit by means of the pp) , but cannot quit right there under controln of this CLI util. 

In the scope of this task it's meant to supply `quit` option for each possible choise set. 
Thus automated interation can rely on it and have safe choise for exit.
